First we need to load the saved state of the attribute we are going to use to save the state of the IAP. We need a game attribute (or table, if there are multiple IAPs) to save the state so we donâ€™t need to depend on an internet connection to fill the PurchaseTable. If we donâ€™t use a game attribute and the user doesnâ€™t have an internet connection, there is no way to know if they have purchased the IAP or not. We store this using the â€œgame.Item Purchasedâ€ attribute. ğŸ”š
When the user presses the Buy Now button

When the user presses the Buy Now button, we have to check a number of attributes to see if the button is currently pressable. We first check if the IAP has already been bought, by ensuring the â€œgame.Item Purchasedâ€ attribute is false. If itâ€™s true, this button is disabled and we can reject any press. We also need to check if either a buy or restore is already in progress, and we do this by ensuring the â€œgame.Buyingâ€ and â€œgame.Restoringâ€ attributes are false. ğŸ”š

Since the user has pressed the button, we need to provide some feedback. We do this by changing the buttonâ€™s image to one telling the user to wait. This reassures the user that their press of the button has had some action. If we donâ€™t change the image, it is likely to be a few seconds before they get Appleâ€™s login or confirm purchase popups. ğŸ”š

The restore button also needs to know that the user pressed the Buy button. You could possibly rely on the 5th column of the PurchaseTable to notify the Restore button - this will soon be changed from â€œunpurchasedâ€ to â€œpendingâ€. However, using that method relies on the table being filled with a Request Purchase Data behaviour, and weâ€™re wanting to avoid triggering that until the user presses a button, so we need to rely on a game (or scene) attribute instead. We set that to true here.
Additionally, since weâ€™re not calling the Request Purchase Data behaviour until the button is pressed, we need an attribute to trigger the actual purchase once the table is filled. ğŸ”š

Now we need to actually call the Request Purchase Data behaviour, and fill the PurchaseTable. First though we need to check that it hasnâ€™t already been successfully filled. When you use a Request Purchase Data behaviour, it will fill the callback attribute you define with a 1 if it has succeeded, or a -1 if it has failed. If the callback attribute is not 1, the table has either not been attempted to be filled or has failed to fill, and we can trigger the Request Purchase Data behaviour.
The â€œCallbackâ€ attribute needs to be a game attribute so that the Restore button can also have access to the state of the table. Again we could use the contents of the 5th column of the PurchaseTable, but since we have to use an attribute to use the behaviour we might as well put it to full use. ğŸ”š

Once the PurchaseTable has been successfully filled, GameSalad will change the â€œgame.Callbackâ€ attribute to 1. As soon as this happens, we can get on with the actual Buying. ğŸ”š

We only need to trigger the Buy behaviour if the player has pressed the Buy button. We are only ever going to allow a Buy to take place when the PurchaseTable has been filled, so we need to have that as a condition. We could actually combine these two rules into one rule with two conditions, but for this Tutorial Template itâ€™s a clearer sequence of events if we separate them out.
If the PurchaseTable has been filled and the user has pressed the Buy button, triggering the â€œgame.Buyingâ€ attribute, we make the actual purchase attempt. ğŸ”š

In a real game, the moment the Purchase behaviour is triggered, GameSalad will change the 5th column of the PurchaseTable to â€œpendingâ€. This happens automatically in a properly made ad hoc build, but doesnâ€™t happen in Creator, Preview, or some types of ad hoc. Including this Change Table Value just saves us from having to press the â€œPendingâ€ button thatâ€™s included in this Tutorial Template for illustrative and testing purposes.

When â€œgame.Callbackâ€ is 1, and â€œgame.Buyingâ€ is true, we can safely expect the cell in the 5th column of the PurchaseTable to say â€œpendingâ€, as outlined above. This means that if both these conditions are valid and this cell says â€œunpurchasedâ€, we know that purchase has failed - either because a connection could not be established, or more likely because the user pressed â€œCancelâ€. In either case, we need to record that a purchase is no longer being attempted by setting â€œgame.Buyingâ€ to false.

It is extremely unlikely but *possible* that this rule would be evaluated before the Purchase behaviour has been triggered and the cell changed to â€œpendingâ€. Worst case scenario is that the purchase is cancelled prematurely and the user has to trigger it again. ğŸ”š

Since the purchase failed, for whatever reason, we may want to indicate this to the user by changing the Buy buttonâ€™s image to reflect this failure. This is entirely optional, and if you do choose to do so you may want to revert the image back to the normal image after a set period of time, perhaps 3 seconds. We do this in a rule at the end. ğŸ”š

If the PurchaseTable cannot be filled - for whatever reason - GameSalad will return a value of -1 using the â€œgame.Callbackâ€ attribute. If this happens, we need to record that the purchase attempt has failed and keep trying to fill the PurchaseTable at set intervals. Until the table is successfully filled, both the Buy and Restore buttons will display an image that indicates this failure to connect to Appleâ€™s servers to fill the table.

The PurchaseTable couldnâ€™t be filled, so there was a problem with the connection. We change the Buy buttonâ€™s image to reflect this. ğŸ”š
Without being able to talk to Apple, thereâ€™s no point trying to make a purchase, so we set â€œgame.Buyingâ€ back to false, cancelling the purchase attempt. ğŸ”š

If the player presses the Restore button, we need to show that this action is in progress by changing the image of the Buy button too. We do that here. Just as we used a â€œgame.Buyingâ€ attribute to indicate when a Buy is in progress, we use the â€œgame.Restoringâ€ attribute to show when a Restore is in progress. ğŸ”š

Since a Restore has been requested but not yet completed, we need to change the Buy buttonâ€™s image to our â€œPlease waitâ€ image. As soon as the Restore is completed, weâ€™ll either change the image back to our normal Buy button image, which happens below in the â€œRe-enable button when usableâ€ rule, or replace it with the disabled image using the â€œThe IAP is successfully boughtâ€ rule above. ğŸ”š

But if you do want to restore the default image, we just need to use a timer that changes the image after the desired interval.
